intro: Cracca bicolor, commonly known as the two-colored cracca, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its slender, upright stems and finely divided leaves. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, which are typical of the family. Cracca bicolor is often found in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to withstand periods of drought. It is also valued in traditional medicine for its purported health benefits.
